citations.narrative:
The licensee stated that she sold at least 1 juvenile marmoset last week from her property in Florida, which has not been
inspected and approved for regulated activity by USDA officials. The licensee had previously (and recently) been informed
by USDA officials that no regulated activity may occur at this location until it is inspected and approved by USDA
personnel. Inspection and approval of locations (sites) where animals are housed is essential for ensuring animal welfare
and compliance with the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by March 3, 2023 by only conducting regulated
activity (including breeding, selling, and exhibiting AWA-covered animals) at sites/locations that have been inspected and
approved by USDA officials.

The licensee stated that she had obtained health certificates for 2 juvenile spider monkeys sold in the summer of 2022,
however, the licensee also stated that she did not save copies of the health certificates. Copies of the health certificates
could not be located the veterinary clinic where they were issued or the state office where health certificates are filed.
Health certificates are essential for ensuring that animals are healthy and fit for travel. Correct from this day forward
(3/3/2023) by keeping copies of health certificates and all other required records, documents, and other papers required
to be kept and maintained under the AWA for at least 1 year.

citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
On August 10th, 2022 the licensee knowingly purchased a male marmoset from an unlicensed individual. The seller did
not have a variance from USDA Animal Care for the sale of the animal. The licensee stated that she thought it was okay
to purchase animals from unlicensed individuals as long as it was done rarely. Animals sold by individuals who are
required to have a USDA license but who do not have a valid USDA license may suffer from poor welfare. Correct from
this day forward (3/3/2023) by obtaining animals only from persons or facilities that currently hold a valid licensed under
the Animal Welfare Act, when such licensure for the sale of the animal is required.
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative, and exit interview was conducted with the licensee.
End Section

narrative:
2.1(b)(1) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee stated that she sold at least 1 juvenile marmoset last week from her property in Florida, which has not been 
inspected and approved for regulated activity by USDA officials. The licensee had previously (and recently) been informed 
by USDA officials that no regulated activity may occur at this location until it is inspected and approved by USDA 
personnel. Inspection and approval of locations (sites) where animals are housed is essential for ensuring animal welfare 
and compliance with the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by March 3, 2023 by only conducting regulated 
activity (including breeding, selling, and exhibiting AWA-covered animals) at sites/locations that have been inspected and 
approved by USDA officials. 
2.80(a) 
   
Records, disposition. 
The licensee stated that she had obtained health certificates for 2 juvenile spider monkeys sold in the summer of 2022, 
however, the licensee also stated that she did not save copies of the health certificates. Copies of the health certificates 
could not be located the veterinary clinic where they were issued or the state office where health certificates are filed. 
Health certificates are essential for ensuring that animals are healthy and fit for travel. Correct from this day forward

(3/3/2023) by keeping copies of health certificates and all other required records, documents, and other papers required 
to be kept and maintained under the AWA for at least 1 year. 
2.132(d)  Critical
   
Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers. 
On August 10th, 2022 the licensee knowingly purchased a male marmoset from an unlicensed individual. The seller did 
not have a variance from USDA Animal Care for the sale of the animal. The licensee stated that she thought it was okay 
to purchase animals from unlicensed individuals as long as it was done rarely. Animals sold by individuals who are 
required to have a USDA license but who do not have a valid USDA license may suffer from poor welfare. Correct from 
this day forward (3/3/2023) by obtaining animals only from persons or facilities that currently hold a valid licensed under 
the Animal Welfare Act, when such licensure for the sale of the animal is required. 
 
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative, and exit interview was conducted with the licensee. 
 
End Section
